title: 110_hr1706
content: The Act titled "United States Specialty Crop Export Opportunities Act of 2007" regulates exports of plants, plant products, biological control organisms, and noxious weeds under the Agricultural Risk Protection Act of 2000. The Secretary has the authority to regulate plants, plant products, biological control organisms, and noxious weeds for export purposes. They are required to coordinate market analyses for fruits and vegetables and make information on export petitions and import requirements available on a website. Regulations may be issued to implement this section. The Secretary may issue regulations to implement this section. "Sec. 420 regulates exports of plants, plant products, biological control organisms, and noxious weeds. SEC. 3 restores import and entry agricultural inspection functions to the Department of Agriculture." The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is being amended to repeal the transfer of functions and make conforming amendments to the Secretary of Homeland Security's role. A transfer agreement between the Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of Homeland Security will be made to return functions, potentially allowing the use of certain employees for carrying out authorities. The Department of Homeland Security will carry out authorities delegated to the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service for protecting domestic livestock and plants. All Department of Agriculture positions transferred to Homeland Security will be restored. The Secretary of Agriculture will establish the International Agricultural Inspection Program within APHIS. The "Agricultural Inspection Program" authorizes the Administrator of the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service to conduct import and entry agricultural inspections. The Administrator has access to secure areas of terminals controlled by the Department of Homeland Security for inspections and information gathering. Additionally, they have access to databases related to cargo manifests and employee records under Homeland Security's control. The Administrator of the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service has access to secure areas controlled by the Department of Homeland Security for inspections and information gathering. They may issue inspection alerts for immediate cargo inspection and continue to collect agricultural quarantine inspection user fees. Additionally, a career track program is established to support the development of long-term agriculture inspector careers. The Administrator of the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, in coordination with the Secretary of Agriculture, is developing a strategic plan to incorporate import and entry agricultural inspectors into protecting the US from animal and plant pests. Training will be provided for these inspectors as part of the plan. The Secretary of Agriculture is required to develop standard operating procedures for import and entry agricultural inspections, in accordance with recommendations from the Comptroller General of the United States. Additionally, the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service must have a national electronic system for monitoring with real-time tracking capability. The Secretary of Agriculture must establish real-time tracking for monitoring and reporting inspection activities. A communication system will be developed to alert State departments of agriculture about significant inspection findings. An International Trade Inspection Advisory Committee will also be established. The Secretary of Agriculture will establish a committee to advise on import and entry agricultural inspection policies. The committee will include members from State departments of agriculture, directors of ports and airports, the transportation industry, and the public. The Secretary of Agriculture will submit an annual report to Congress assessing resource needs for import agricultural inspection, adequacy of inspection procedures and facilities, and new technologies and practices. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide recommendations to improve import and entry agricultural inspection, with funding for inspectors coming from the Department of Agriculture or the Commodity Credit Corporation. The amendments made by this section will take effect 180 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. REPORTS OF TRADE ADVISORY COMMITTEES. The Agricultural Policy Committee on Trade and the Agricultural Technical Advisory Committee on Trade in Fruits and Vegetables must provide recommendations to the United States Trade Representative and relevant congressional committees. SEC. 5. REPORT ON FOREIGN AGRICULTURAL SERVICE STAFFING LEVELS FOR MONITORING OTHER COUNTRIES' COMPLIANCE WITH TRADE AGREEMENTS. The Secretary of Agriculture must submit a report to Congress within 60 days, evaluating the Foreign Agricultural Service's ability to monitor other countries' compliance with trade agreements. The report should also include recommendations on filling vacancies in the monitoring office. Additionally, a feasibility report on export indemnification for unsubsidized commodities is required. The Secretary of Agriculture must submit a report to Congress by January 1, 2008, evaluating the feasibility and cost of establishing an indemnity program for exporters of articles classified under chapters 7 and 8 of the Harmonized Tariff Schedule. This program would compensate exporters when their articles are wrongfully denied entry into foreign countries despite complying with all export and import requirements. The United States Trade Representative will propose excluding articles classified under chapters 7 and 8 of the Harmonized Tariff Schedule from the Agreement on Agriculture in the Doha Round negotiations. Additionally, there will be a special export credit guarantee program. The Secretary of Agriculture will establish a special export credit guarantee program similar to existing regulations, with eligibility for exporters or importers in foreign countries, a 45-day guarantee period, and a cost not exceeding 45 cents per $100 of coverage. Additionally, there will be authorization levels for the emerging market credit program. Authorization levels for the emerging market credit program under the Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act of 1990 are amended to increase the limit from $10,000,000 to $20,000,000. Definitions for NAFTA and Uruguay Round Agreements are also provided in the Act.
